titlestmt.titleproper: Edward A. Dickson Cuneiform Tablet collection, Ur III period-Neo-Babylonian period (ca. 2100-562 BCE) LSC.1813

did.unittitle: Edward A. Dickson Cuneiform Tablet collection
did.abstract: The majority of the eight tablets are administrative in nature, citing loans, receipts, and inventories. Most of the administrative texts date to the Ur III period (Third Dynasty of Ur). One tablet contains a royal inscription from the Early Old Babylonian period (ca. 2000-1800 BCE) on a clay cone. This collection was donated to UCLA by Edward A. Dickson.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

accessrestrict.head: Restrictions on Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use and Reproduction
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Edward A. Dickson Cuneiform Tablet collection (Collection 1813). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Note
processinfo.p: Transliterations by Justin Cale Johnson. Processed by Sara Brumfield in the Center for Primary Research and Training (CFPRT), with assistance from Kelley Wolfe Bachli, 2008.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Potentially Offensive Description in Library Special Collections.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: Edward Augustus Dickson donated his collection of tablets to the University of California-Los Angeles. Dickson was one of the founding fathers of the Los Angeles campus for the California university system. He was appointed to Board of Regents in 1912 and served until his death in 1956, at the age of 76.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The majority of texts in this collection are administrative in nature, citing loans, receipts, and inventories. All but one of the administrative texts date to the Ur III period (Third Dynasty of Ur), known for its abundance of economic documents. During the Ur III period (ca. 2100-2004 BCE), the state reached a level of centralization that was unprecedented. To accommodate the large population of workers and products under this state run economy, written records of business transactions and inventories were constantly issued.

The collection also contains a royal inscription from the Early Old Babylonian period (ca. 2000-1800 BCE) on a clay cone. Clay cones were often used to commemorate the building of monumental architecture. An inscription praising the king and his deities would be written around the cone on its vertical axis. Then the cone would be inserted into the wall of the structure obscuring the inscription from human eyes.

The cone is from the reign of Lipit-Ishtar (ca.1934-1924 BCE). His seat of power was in the city of Isin. Lipit-Ishtar is best known for his set of laws, issued even before Hammurabi's famous law code. When Lipit-Ishtar published his law code, he also built the Enisisa (literally, "house of justice") and he had its construction recorded on over a hundred clay cones, of which this is just one.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p: Tablets are described at the item level.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Cumberland Clark Cuneiform Tablet Collection (Collection 1826). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

altformavail.head: Online Items Available
altformavail.p: Portions of this collection have been digitized and are available online: CDLI contributors. 2023. "Special Collections, UCLA, Los Angeles, California, USA - Collections." Cuneiform Digital Library Initiative. May 25, 2023. https://cdli.mpiwg-berlin.mpg.de/collections/1072.

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of sheep and goats from Drehem in the 5th month of the 8th year of Amar-Suen's reign

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Puzriš-Dagan (mod. Drehem), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Puzriš-Dagan (mod. Drehem), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: List of sheep and goats from Drehem, Iraq dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE). The 8th year of Amar-Suen's reign dates to 2039 BCE. The festival of Ninazu is the 5th month of the Drehem calendar year.

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of sheep and goats from Drehem in the 5th month of the 47th year of Shulgi's reign

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of sheep and goats from Drehem, Iraq dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE). The 47th year of Shulgi's reign dates to 2048 BCE. The festival of Ninazu is the 5th month of the Drehem calendar year.

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of types of grain from Umma in the 1st year of Ibbi-Suen's reign

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Lists of different types of grain from Umma, Iraq dating to the reign of Ibbi-Suen (c. 2030 BCE). The first year of Ibbi-Suen's reign dates to 2028 BCE. The month that "the brick was placed in the brick mold" is the second month of Umma's calendar year.

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Umma (mod. Tell Jokha), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Umma (mod. Tell Jokha), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A note describing a reed mat(?) of unknown provenience dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE).

did.unittitle: Adminstrative tablet of sheep and goats from Drehem in the 42nd year of Shulgi's reign

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Puzriš-Dagan (mod. Drehem), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Puzriš-Dagan (mod. Drehem), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of sheep and goats from Drehem, Iraq dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE). The 42nd year of Shulgi's reign dates to 2053 BCE. The month of "eating the gazelle" is the first month of Drehem's calendar year.

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of sheep and goats from Drehem in the 4th year of Amar-Suen's reign

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Ur III (ca. 2100-2000 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: List of sheep and goats from Drehem, Iraq dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE). The 4th year of Amar-Suen's reign dates to 2042 BCE. The month of An's festival is the 10th month of Drehem's calendar year.

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of hired workers in Umma from the Ur III period.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: A list of two hired workers and oxen from Umma, Iraq dating to the Ur III period (2100-2000 BCE). Currently missing from Special Collections holdings.

did.unittitle: Royal inscription from the reign of Lipit-Ishtar

dao.xlink:title: Official or display cone excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Early Old Babylonian (ca. 2000-1900 BC) period

daodesc.p: Official or display cone excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Early Old Babylonian (ca. 2000-1900 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Royal inscription of Lipit-Ishtar on a clay cone dating to the Old Babylonian period. Lipit-Ishtar was king in Mesopotamia for ten years between 1934-1924 BCE. Lipit- Ishtar ruled from the city of Isin and is famous for issuing a set of laws. When he published his laws, Lipit-Ishtar also built Enisisa, the "House of Justice," and he had its construction recorded on lots of clay cones like this one. Note: this text = RIME 4.1.5.4 (Frayne 1990, 52-54). For another exemplar of this inscription see: http://special.lib.umn.edu/rare/cuneiform/UM15.phtml

did.unittitle: Administrative tablet of a silver loan from the reign of Nebuchadnezzar II

dao.xlink:title: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Neo-Babylonian (ca. 626-539 BC) period

daodesc.p: Administrative tablet excavated in Uncertain (mod. uncertain), dated to the Neo-Babylonian (ca. 626-539 BC) period

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Citing loan of silver and witnesses involved dating to the reign of Nebuchadnezzar II in the Neo-Babylonian period. Nebuchadnezzar II was king of Mesopotamia from 604-562 BCE.
